contentrichtext.text: '''Baron Bruntisfield''', of Boroughmuir in the City of Edinburgh, is a title in the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom]]. It was created in 1942 for the [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] politician and former [[Vice-Chamberlain of the Household]], [[Victor Warrender, 1st Baron Bruntisfield|Sir Victor Warrender, 8th Baronet]]. The Warrender family descends from [[Sir George Warrender, 1st Baronet|George Warrender]]. He was [[Lord Provost of Edinburgh]] and represented [[Edinburgh (UK Parliament constituency)|Edinburgh]] in Parliament. In 1715 he was created a baronet, of Lochend in the County of Haddington, in the [[Baronetage of Great Britain]].<ref>{{London Gazette| issue = 5330 | startpage = 1 | date = 17 May 1715 | accessdate = 9 April 2009 }}</ref> His grandson, the third Baronet, fought at the [[Battle of Minden]] in 1759, represented [[Haddington Burghs (UK Parliament constituency)|Haddington Burghs]] in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] and served as [[King's Remembrancer|King’s Remembrancer of the Court of Exchequer]] from 1771 to 1791. He was succeeded by his son, the fourth Baronet. He sat as a [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Haddington Burghs (UK Parliament constituency)|Haddington Burghs]], [[Truro (UK Parliament constituency)|Truro]], [[Sandwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Sandwich]], [[Westbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Westbury]] and [[Honiton (UK Parliament constituency)|Honiton]] and notably served as a [[Lord of the Admiralty]] from 1812 to 1812. In 1822 Warrender was admitted to the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Council]]. On his death the title passed to his younger brother, the fifth Baronet. His grandson, the seventh Baronet, was a [[Vice Admiral]] in the [[Royal Navy]]. He was succeeded by his son, the eighth Baronet, who was raised to the peerage as '''Baron Bruntisfield''', of Boroughmuir in the City of Edinburgh, in 1942. {{As of|2010}} the titles are held by the latter's grandson, the third Baron, who succeeded in 2007. He is a retired officer in the [[British Army]] and [[investment banker]]. ==Warrender baronets, of Lochend (1715)== *[[Sir George Warrender, 1st Baronet]] (c. 1658–1721) *Sir John Warrender, 2nd Baronet (c. 1686–1772) *[[Sir Patrick Warrender, 3rd Baronet]] (1731–1799) *[[Sir George Warrender, 4th Baronet]] (1782–1849) *Sir John Warrender, 5th Baronet (1786–1867) *Sir George Warrender, 6th Baronet (1825–1901) *[[Sir George Warrender, 7th Baronet]] (1860–1917) *[[Victor Warrender, 1st Baron Bruntisfield|Sir Victor Alexander George Anthony Warrender, 8th Baronet]] (1899–1993) (created '''Baron Bruntisfield''' in 1942) ==Barons Bruntisfield (1942)== *[[Victor Warrender, 1st Baron Bruntisfield|Victor Alexander George Anthony Warrender, 1st Baron Bruntisfield]] (1899–1993) *[[John Warrender, 2nd Baron Bruntisfield|John Robert Warrender, 2nd Baron Bruntisfield]] (1921–2007) *[[Michael Warrender, 3rd Baron Bruntisfield|Michael John George Warrender, 3rd Baron Bruntisfield]] (b. 1949) The [[heir apparent]] is the present holder's son the Hon. John Michael Patrick Caspar Warrender (b. 1996) ==References== {{reflist}} *Kidd, Charles, Williamson, David (editors). ''Debrett's Peerage and Baronetage'' (1990 edition). New York: St Martin's Press, 1990. *{{Rayment|date=February 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bruntisfield}} [[Category:Baronies in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1715 establishments in Great Britain]] [[Category:1942 establishments in the United Kingdom]]
